channel.title: Interleaved RSS Feed
channel.description: This is an interleaved feed of the most recent entries from each RSS source, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Ukraine’s Incursion Into Russia: What to Know
item.description: The incursion caught Russia by surprise and signified a shift in tactics for Kyiv after more than two years of war with Russia.

item.title: Ukraine’s Incursion Into Russia: What to Know
item.description: The incursion caught Russia by surprise and signified a shift in tactics for Kyiv after more than two years of war with Russia.

item.title: Extreme heat and humidity are causing 47,000 deaths across Europe—here’s what it does to the human body
item.description: The world’s two hottest days on record happened in July and 2024 is on track to be the warmest year ever.

item.title: Jim Foley’s Legacy Helped Change Hostage Policy
item.description: Americans held captive overseas deserve all of our help.

item.title: Blinken Travels to Israel Amid Push for Gaza Cease-Fire
item.description: The secretary of state’s trip comes days after negotiations in Qatar ended without a major breakthrough.

item.title: The NFL could vote soon on letting private equity firms buy stakes in teams
item.description: The league held meetings with multiple private equity firms this week in the hopes of completing a framework to present to owners.

item.title: Harris Can Change Biden’s Policy on Israel Just by Upholding the Law
item.description: The longstanding Leahy law can — and should — change Middle East policy.

item.title: Russians Fleeing Ukraine’s Advance Border Regions Rush to Kursk
item.description: In the regional capital, those who left their homes as Ukrainian forces tore into western Russia are uncertain whether they can ever return to their old lives.

item.title: U.S. supply chains at risk as Canada’s top railroads begin shutting down networks amid labor dispute
item.description: Canadian Pacific Kansas City and Canadian National railroads have stopped taking certain shipments of hazardous materials and refrigerated products.

item.title: Blinken Travels to Israel Amid Push for Gaza Cease-Fire
item.description: The secretary of state’s trip comes days after negotiations in Qatar ended without a major breakthrough.

item.title: ‘Bad Blood’ Stalks a Lithium Mine in Serbia
item.description: A Rio Tinto mine that Europe sees as a critical source for electric vehicle batteries has been the target of enormous protests. “I don’t need green cars. I need green apples and green grass,” said one opponent.

item.title: ‘Indiana Jones’ fedora fetches $630,000 at auction while ‘Star Wars’ helmet gets $315,000
item.description: The hat featured in 1984's “Indiana Jones and the Temple of Doom” was expected to fetch between $250,000 and $500,000, according to the item's online description.

item.title: Alain Delon, French Film Star, Dead at 88
item.description: The César-winning actor was an international favorite in the 1960s and ’70s, often sought after by the era’s great auteurs.

item.title: Venezuelans Mourn Loved Ones Killed in Protests, and Last Shreds of Democracy
item.description: The nation is in anguish as it buries its dead and enters a new era of authoritarianism.

item.title: Goldman Sachs trims recession odds to 20% from 25% on strong data
item.description: If the August jobs report “looks reasonably good, we would probably cut our recession probability back to 15%,” economists led by Jan Hatzius said in a note Saturday.
